config.question: Which of the following geographic features could be found in the Great Plains beyond the Missouri timber country?

answer_3.response: Emerging from the timber country, travelers first encountered the Great Plains—treeless, nearly flat, an endless “sea of grassy hillocks” extending from the Mississippi River to the Rocky Mountains. Few rivers cut through the Plains; those that did raged in the winter and trickled in the summer. Rainfall usually did not reach 15 inches a year, and the tools of eastern settlement—the cast-iron plow and the ax—were virtually useless on the tough and treeless Plains soil.
